chunks.chunk_text: Well, I eat lots of fresh fruit and vegetables and only a little meat from time to time. Well, while many diets claim to improve health or help you lose weight, recent research shows that what counts is not what you eat, but how your body reacts.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Are personalised diets the best way to be healthy_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Inside everyone's gut are millions of microbes – tiny living organisms too small to see without a microscope. Some of them are good for us, some bad. This mix of gut microbes is unique and different for everyone – even
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Are personalised diets the best way to be healthy_.json

chunks.chunk_text: identical twins. And it's the reason why some doctors now recommend a personalised diet – one that perfectly fits your own unique combination of microbes. We'll hear more soon, but first I have a question for you, Neil, and it's about the gut – the tube which includes the large and small intestine. It's very long, but how long exactly is the average adult's gut?
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Are personalised diets the best way to be healthy_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Well, everybody is different of course, but I'll say on average the gut is b – five and a half metres long. OK, Neil, I'll reveal the answer later in the programme.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Are personalised diets the best way to be healthy_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Listen to Dr Spector explain how he started to doubt some of this advice – food myths, he calls them, to BBC Radio 4 programme The Life Scientific. All these so-called myths that I'd believed, whether it was about calories, about fats, when to eat, how to eat, were based on flimsy or no evidence, very old, very poor quality, and had been repeated so much that people didn't think to question them.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Are personalised diets the best way to be healthy_.json

chunks.chunk_text: What Dr Spector questioned was counting calories – the units which measure the amount of energy food provides. He discovered that much of the dietary advice he had heard was either incorrect or based on flimsy evidence. If evidence is flimsy, it's weak and unconvincing. As Dr Spector questioned these food myths, he remembered an earlier study involving identical twins – pairs of brothers or sisters with the same genes.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Are personalised diets the best way to be healthy_.json

chunks.chunk_text: It was the surprising differences in weight between one twin and another that made Dr Spector realise that no two people have the same gut – even identical twins' guts are different. But as he told BBC Radio 4's The Life Scientific, the discovery came in a very smelly way – by asking his volunteers to send samples of their poo in the post.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Are personalised diets the best way to be healthy_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Although genetically identical, one twin was overweight, while the other twin was skinny or very thin.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Are personalised diets the best way to be healthy_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Because the weight difference could not be explained genetically, Dr Spector suspected the microbes in the skinnier twin's gut held the answer. The more diverse someone's microbes, the better their gut was at digesting food, regulating fat and maintaining health.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Are personalised diets the best way to be healthy_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Since everyone's microbes are different, it follows that a personalised diet which selects the friendliest food for your gut is best. Right, and all this talk of eating is making me hungry. So, tell me, Sam, was my answer to your question right? Ah, yes. I asked about the length of the gut in the average adult. I said it was five and a half metres. Which was the correct answer. Well done, Neil. That took guts, which is the second meaning of the word – courage.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Are personalised diets the best way to be healthy_.json

chunks.chunk_text: OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned, starting with gut – an informal word for the intestines – the tube which digests food from the stomach.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Are personalised diets the best way to be healthy_.json

chunks.chunk_text: It's noticeable in a good way. Unfortunately, our six minutes are up, but remember – look after your gut and your gut will look after you. Goodbye.
